lamblin.common.runningmedian

Class RangeRunningMedian<T extends java.lang.Number & java.lang.Comparable<T>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • lamblin.common.runningmedian.RangeRunningMedian<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    RunningMedian<T>

    public class RangeRunningMedian<T extends java.lang.Number & java.lang.Comparable<T>>
extends java.lang.Object
implements RunningMedian<T>
    Updates a running median for all the data input with each update of added data.

    If we know the range of possible integer inputs to update, as a tweet would never never be more than 70 words, then we can, unlike the QueueRunningMedian, not store each input, but rather the number of times each possible input in the range has been seen.

    Combined with a total of how many inputs have been seen, we need only count half that total into the sums from the beginning of the range onwards, identifying the mean in constant O(1) time. It's also possible to store the data in constant O(1) time. Memory use remains bounded to the size of range number of inputs.

    Limitations are that the number of inputs total should be less than a long's maximum value and similarly that the number of any one integer value inputs should be less as well. Also the number of buckets should be less than integer's maximum value.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      RangeRunningMedian(java.lang.Long minimumIncluded, java.lang.Long maximumIncluded, java.lang.Long finestInterval)
      Will allocate a number of buckets, like a histogram, starting at minimumIncluded, increasing by finestInterval until maximumIncluded.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

    • Constructor Detail

      • RangeRunningMedian

        public RangeRunningMedian(java.lang.Long minimumIncluded,
                          java.lang.Long maximumIncluded,
                          java.lang.Long finestInterval)
        Will allocate a number of buckets, like a histogram, starting at minimumIncluded, increasing by finestInterval until maximumIncluded. All updates must have input values which fall in these buckets.

        This is not concurrent.

        Parameters:
        minimumIncluded - the smallest value an update can be
        maximumIncluded - the largest value an update can be
        finestInterval - the distribution of values between these; recommend integer like 1.

    • Method Detail

      • update

        public java.lang.Double update(T input)
        Increment the count at the input's bucket, and return a median.
        Specified by:
        update in interface RunningMedian<T extends java.lang.Number & java.lang.Comparable<T>>
        Parameters:
        input - the value to add
        Returns:
        the median of all values added thus far
